questions.question: In the given CT slice, A and B respectively represent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ascending Aorta, Descending Aorta Explanation: The CT slice is at the level of T5, in which A represents the ascending aorta & B represents descending aorta .

questions.question: The pleural cupola is located:

options.A: Above the diaphragm, covering the lower lung
options.B: Over the apex of the lung, reaching 2 to 3 cm above the clavicle
options.C: Near the midline of the chest at the level of the heart
options.D: At the base of the lungs, covered by the suprapleural membrane

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Over the apex of the lung, reaching 2 to 3 cm above the clavicle Explanation: Cervical Pleura Extends from the inner border of the 1st rib. Covers the apex of the lung. Passes downwards and medially to continue with the mediastinal pleura. Pleural Cupola Forms a cup-like dome over the apex of the lung. The summit of the dome reaches 2 to 3 cm higher than the medial third of the clavicle, at the level of the neck of the first rib. Suprapleural Membrane (Sibson’s Fascia) Covers the cervical pleura externally. A musculo-fascial expansion derived from the scalenus minimus muscle and endothoracic fascia. Extends from the tip of the transverse process of the 7th cervical vertebra to the inner border of the 1st rib. Medially continuous with the pretracheal fascia by the side of the trachea. Relation to Structures All structures related to the apex of the lung are superficial to the suprapleural membrane. Reference: Inderbir Singhs Textbook of Anatomy, Volume 1, 6th Edition, Page 56

questions.question: Where is pain from the mediastinal pleura typically referred?

options.D: In the lower back near the kidneys

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Over the ipsilateral shoulder Explanation: Pleura Structure and Function Visceral Pleura: Surrounds lung tissue. Composed of a single mesothelial cell layer. Blood supply from bronchial arteries. Parietal Pleura: Lines the inner chest wall. Contains stomata that drain pleural fluid into lymphatic capillaries. Connective tissue present; innervated by sensory nerve fibers. Pleural Fluid Normal Volume: 0.1 to 0.2 mL/kg. Inflow Rate: 0.5 mL/hr in adults. Maximal Removal Rate: 0.28 mL/kg/hr. Accumulates when inflow exceeds removal (due to increased plasma filtration or impaired lymphatic drainage). Lymphatic Drainage Lymph drains into regional lymph nodes along the sternum or vertebra, then into the thoracic and right lymphatic ducts. Lymphatic vessels are 10-12 µ m in diameter, large enough for intact erythrocytes. Innervation Visceral Pleura: No connective tissue; innervated by the vagus nerve, insensitive to pain. Parietal Pleura: Connective tissue; innervated by intercostal nerves and phrenic nerve. Phrenic Nerve: Predominantly innervates the central diaphragmatic region, referred pain to the ipsilateral shoulder. Pleural Membrane Function Allows frictionless movement of the lungs relative to the chest wall during respiration. Inspiration: Negative pressure in the pleural space leads to lung expansion, allowing air to enter the lungs Reference: Pain

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the cardiac plexuses? trachea. except the inferior cervical cardiac branch of the left vagus nerve. plexus. sympathetic chain.

options.A: The superficial cardiac plexus is located behind the arch of the aorta, in front of the bifurcation of the
options.B: The deep cardiac plexus receives cardiac branches from the vagus and recurrent laryngeal nerves,
options.C: The superficial cardiac plexus distributes to the left coronary artery and right anterior pulmonary
options.D: The deep cardiac plexus is formed only by the superior cervical cardiac branch of the left

questions.explanation: laryngeal nerves, except the inferior cervical cardiac branch of the left vagus nerve. Correct Answer: B) The deep cardiac plexus receives cardiac branches from the vagus and recurrent laryngeal nerves, except the inferior cervical cardiac branch of the left vagus nerve. Explanation: Cardiac ganglion of Wrisberg, also called the juxta ductal body or the aortico-pulmonary ganglionic mass. Cardiac Plexuses Superficial Cardiac Plexus: Location: Below the arch of the aorta, in front of the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk, to the right of the ligamentum arteriosum (Option A) Cardiac Ganglion of Wrisberg : Located close to the ligamentum arteriosum. Formation: (a) Superior cervical cardiac branch of the left cervical sympathetic trunk. (b) Inferior cervical cardiac branch of the left vagus nerve. Distribution: (Option C) (a) Deep cardiac plexus. (b) Right coronary artery. (c) Left anterior pulmonary plexus. Deep Cardiac Plexus: Location: In front of the bifurcation of the trachea, behind the arch of the aorta. Formation: (a) Cardiac branches from three cervical and upper 4-5 thoracic ganglia of the sympathetic chains (except the superior cervical cardiac branch of the left sympathetic chain) (Option D) (b) Cardiac branches from the vagus and recurrent laryngeal nerves (except the inferior cervical cardiac branch of the left vagus nerve) (Option B) Distribution: Right and left halves of the plexus: (a) Corresponding coronary arteries. (b) Pulmonary plexus. (c) Separate branches to the atria. The illustration below shows Deep cardiac plexus

questions.question: An axial CT scan of the thorax shows a slice where the aortic arch is visible, along with the trachea bifurcating into the main bronchi. At which anatomical level is this axial section most likely taken?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) T3-T4 Explanation: At this level, the aortic arch is usually seen, and the trachea begins to bifurcate into the right and left main bronchi. Level of the Thoracic Inlet : This is at the top of the thoracic cavity, where the trachea and esophagus enter. Level of the Aortic Arch : Located around the T4-T5 vertebral level, where the aorta arches over the left main bronchus. Level of the Carina : At the T5-T6 level, this is where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi. Level of the Heart : The heart is typically seen from T6 to T9 . You can identify the chambers (right atrium, left atrium, ventricles) and major vessels (aorta, pulmonary arteries). Level of the Diaphragm : The diaphragm typically corresponds to the T10 vertebral level, which can help in distinguishing between thoracic and abdominal structures. Level of the Esophagus : The esophagus runs along the midline and can be seen at various levels, usually starting from the cervical region down to T10. Level of the Thoracic Spine : The thoracic vertebrae can be used as references; typically, there are 12 thoracic vertebrae. T1-T2 (Option A): This level generally shows the upper mediastinum, including parts of the great vessels, but the aortic arch is not typically prominent. T5-T6 (Option C): Here, the main bronchi are visible, but the aortic arch may not be well-defined. T7-T8 (Option D): This level typically shows the lower mediastinum and may not include the aortic arch or the bifurcation of the trachea.

questions.question: Which of the following structures is commonly associated with a notable impression on the left lung?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Aorta Explanation : The left lung shows an impression from the aortic arch, which arches over the left main bronchus. Lung impressions refer to the indentations or impressions made on the surface of the lungs by adjacent structures in the thoracic cavity. Right lung impressions Left lung impressions Cardiac Impression (Right Atrium & Auricle) Superior Vena Cava (SVC) Impression (Option B) Right Ventricle (Small part) Right Brachiocephalic Vein (Lower part) Azygos Vein Impression (Option D) Esophageal Impression (Option C) Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) Impression Tracheal Impression Right Vagus Nerve Impression Right Phrenic Nerve Impression Cardiac Impression (Left Ventricle, Auricle, part of Right Ventricle) Pulmonary Trunk Impression Arch of Aorta Impression Descending Thoracic Aorta Impression Left Subclavian Artery Impression Thoracic Duct Impression Esophageal Impression Left Brachiocephalic Vein Impression Left Vagus Nerve Impression Left Phrenic Nerve Impression Left Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Impression Reference: BD Chaurasia Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Page 267

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient presents with a history of progressive shortness of breath and swelling in the neck. Imaging reveals distended chest wall veins and a mediastinal mass with known metastasis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction Explanation: The presence of distended chest wall veins (collaterals) is highly indicative of increased venous pressure, commonly associated with superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction. In this case, the history of a mediastinal mass and metastasis suggests that the mass is compressing the SVC, leading to venous obstruction. This obstruction can cause the characteristic collateral circulation (distended chest wall veins) to develop, as the body attempts to reroute blood flow to bypass the obstruction. The illustration below shows signs of SVC obstruction Right heart failure (Option A) : While this can cause jugular distension, it typically does not lead to the development of prominent chest wall collaterals without

questions.question: A 56-year-old male patient with a history of gastric carcinoma now presents with sharp or pleuritic pain that worsens with deep breaths or coughing. Pleural effusion is suspected and a pleural tap was done which showed the fluid shown in the image. Based on the knowledge of the course of thoracic duct, where does the thoracic duct drain lymph?

options.B: Into the junction of the left subclavian vein and left internal jugular vein
options.C: Directly into the inferior vena cava

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Into the junction of the left subclavian vein and left internal jugular vein disruption or injury to the thoracic duct. Chylothorax is a condition where chyle accumulates in the pleural space, leading to pleural effusion. The thoracic duct drains lymph into the junction of the left subclavian vein and left internal jugular vein. Thoracic duct The thoracic duct starts as the cisterna chyli in the abdomen at the lower border of the T12 vertebra. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. It initially runs on the right side

questions.question: Which part of the body is not drained by the right lymphatic duct?

options.A: Right side of the head and neck

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Right abdomen Explanation: The right lymphatic duct does not drain the right abdomen; this region is typically drained by the thoracic duct, which handles lymph from the lower half of the body, including the abdomen. Right Lymphatic Duct The right lymphatic duct may form from the convergence of the right jugular, subclavian, and bronchomediastinal trunks. These trunks drain lymph from the right side of the head and neck, the right upper limb, and the right side of the thorax. When present, the right lymphatic duct is approximately 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) long. It opens into the beginning of the right brachiocephalic vein. Alternatively, the lymphatic trunks may drain directly into the major veins at the root of the neck. Reference: Snell Clinical Anatomy by Region, 10th edition, Page 264

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the azygos and hemiazygos veins?

options.A: The azygos vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.
options.B: The inferior hemiazygos vein drains into the superior vena cava.
options.C: The superior hemiazygos vein drains into the azygos vein.
options.D: In an obstruction of the SVC, the superior hemiazygos vein acts as the primary collateral pathway.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The superior hemiazygos vein drains into the azygos vein. Explanation: The superior hemiazygos vein drains into the azygos vein at the level of the seventh thoracic vertebra. Azygos Vein The origin of the azygos vein can vary, often starting from the union of the right ascending lumbar vein and the right subcostal vein in the abdomen. It ascends through the aortic opening in the diaphragm, on the right side of the aorta. The vein continues to rise until it reaches the level of the fifth thoracic vertebra. At this level, the azygos vein arches forward above the root of the right lung. It drains into the posterior surface of the superior vena cava. (Option A ruled out) Tributaries: The eight lower right intercostal veins The right superior intercostal vein The superior and inferior hemiazygos veins Mediastinal veins. Pericardial veins Right subcostal vein. Right bronchial vein. Right ascending lumbar vein. If there is an obstruction of the SVC, the azygos vein acts as the primary collateral pathway to redirect blood from the upper half of the body to the IVC. (Option D ruled out) Inferior Hemiazygos Vein The inferior hemiazygos vein is formed by the union of the left ascending lumbar vein and the left subcostal vein in the abdomen. It ascends through the left crus of the diaphragm and, around the level of the eighth thoracic vertebra, it turns to the right to join the azygos vein, receiving tributaries from the lower left intercostal and mediastinal veins. (Option B ruled out) Superior Hemiazygos Vein The superior hemiazygos vein is created by the union of the left superior intercostal vein and the fourth to eighth intercostal veins. It drains into the azygos vein at the level of the seventh thoracic vertebra.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the phrenic nerve is false?

options.A: The phrenic nerve contains both motor and sensory fibers.
options.B: Efferent fibers of the phrenic nerve supply the diaphragm muscle.
options.C: Afferent fibers transmit sensory information from the liver capsule.
options.D: Paralysis of the phrenic nerve can result from pressure from malignant tumors in the mediastinum.

questions.explanation: diaphragm, as well as from the pericardium and mediastinal pleura and not from the liver capsule. Phrenic Nerve The phrenic nerves contain both efferent (motor) and afferent (sensory) fibers . (Option A ruled out) The efferent fibers provide the sole motor supply to the diaphragm muscle. (Option B ruled out) The afferent fibers transmit sensory information to the central nervous system from the peritoneum covering the diaphragm's undersurface, the pleura on the diaphragm's upper surface, and the pericardium and mediastinal parietal pleura. Paralysis of the phrenic nerve may result from pressure from malignant tumors in the mediastinum. (Option D ruled out) Historically, surgical methods like crushing or sectioning the nerve in the neck were used to treat lung tuberculosis affecting the lower lobes, leading to diaphragm paralysis on that side. This causes the elevated, immobile dome of the diaphragm to provide rest to the affected lung. Reference: Snell Clinical Anatomy by Region. 10th edition, Page 265 Grays Anatomy, 42nd edition. Pages 1042-1044

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes a difference between the right and left phrenic nerves?

options.A: The left phrenic nerve is shorter than the right
options.B: The right phrenic nerve passes anterior to the aortic arch
options.C: The left phrenic nerve passes through the caval foramen of the diaphragm
options.D: The right phrenic nerve has a more vertical course in the thorax

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The right phrenic nerve has a more vertical course in the thorax Explanation: The right phrenic nerve (C3, C4, C5) has a more vertical and shorter course through the thorax compared to the left phrenic nerve. Feature Right Phrenic Nerve Left Phrenic Nerve Length and Course Shorter and more vertical Longer and less vertical Relation to Subclavian Artery Separated from second part by scalenus anterior Passes anterior to first part Relation to Major Vessels Passes lateral to superior vena cava Passes anterior to aortic arch Relation to Heart Passes lateral to right atrium Passes over left atrium and left ventricle Diaphragm Entry Through central tendon (caval foramen or just lateral) Through muscular part, anterior to central tendon Associated Ganglion Right phrenic ganglion, sometimes with accessory ganglion Left phrenic ganglion (less common) Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Pages 1042, 1043, 1044

questions.question: Regarding intercostal nerve blocks, which of the following statements is incorrect? insertion

options.A: The intercostal neurovascular bundle is arranged inferior to superior as vein, artery, nerve
options.B: The lateral cutaneous branch of the intercostal nerve arises anterior to the midaxillary line
options.C: The innermost intercostal muscle separates the intercostal nerve from the pleura
options.D: The angle of the rib, approximately 6 to 8 cm from the midline, is used as a landmark for needle

questions.explanation: artery, nerve Correct Answer: A) The intercostal neurovascular bundle is arranged inferior to superior as vein, artery, nerve Explanation: The intercostal neurovascular bundle follows a "VAN" arrangement from superior to inferior: Vein, Artery, Nerve. Intercostal nerve blocks Anatomical Feature Description Neurovascular Bundle Arrangement Superior to inferior: Vein, Artery, Nerve (VAN) Intercostal Nerve Location Inferior border of the rib, in the costal groove Separated from pleura by Innermost intercostal muscle between nerve and pleura (Option C) Landmark for Needle Insertion Angle of the rib, 6-8 cm from midline (Option D) Lateral Cutaneous Branch Arises anterior to the midaxillary line (Option B) Complications Pneumothorax (rare, 0.07% incidence), temporary intercostal muscle paralysis Reference: Miller’s Textbook of Anaesthesia, 9th Edition, Pages 1463, 1464, 1465

questions.question: During a pleural tap procedure, which of the following structures is encountered immediately before reaching the parietal pleura?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Endothoracic fascia Explanation: The endothoracic fascia is the layer encountered immediately before the parietal pleura during a pleural tap procedure. The endothoracic fascia lines the innermost intercostal muscle from inside and is fused with the parietal pleura , making it the last layer encountered before reaching the pleural space where fluid can be aspirated The order of structures punctured during a pleural tap, from superficial to deep: Skin Superficial fascia Serratus anterior (1st muscle to get punctured) External intercostal muscle Internal intercostal muscle Innermost intercostal muscle Endothoracic fascia (Fused with parietal pleura) Parietal pleura Pleural fluid (to be aspirated) Reference: Pubmed

questions.question: A 65-year-old man with a history of congestive heart failure presents with increasing dyspnea. Chest X-ray is given below. The physician decides to perform a thoracentesis. Which of the following anatomical landmarks is most important to be identified, to prevent damage to important structures at its level?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Inferior border of the rib Explanation: The Chest X-ray shows a right sided pleural effusion for which the physician decides to perform thoracocentesis. The inferior border of the rib is the most important anatomical landmark to identify when performing a thoracentesis. This is because the intercostal neurovascular bundle (including the intercostal artery, vein, and nerve) runs along the inferior border of each rib. By inserting the needle just above the superior border of the rib below the intended intercostal space, the risk of damaging these structures is minimized. Pleural Tap : Indications Used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in cases of pleural effusion. The fluid can be analyzed for various factors including culture, cytology, and biochemical analysis. Empyema thoracis for diagnostic purpose Position: The patient should be in a sitting

questions.question: Which of the following structures does not make up the anterior surface (sternocostal) of the heart?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Left atrium Explanation: The left atrium is obscured by the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk, and primarily forms part of the posterior surface, not the anterior surface. Anterior surface of heart (Sternocostal) Posterior View of Heart (Base) The anterior surface consists mainly of the right atrium and right ventricle separated by the anterior atrioventricular groove ( coronary sulcus ). (Option B) The left auricle and left ventricle also contribute. (Option C & D) The right ventricle is separated from the left ventricle by the anterior interventricular groove. The left atrium is obscured by the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk. The heart creates a cardiac notch on the mediastinal surface and anterior border of the left lung causing superficial cardiac dullness The base of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and right atrium (one-third). Major blood vessels like superior vena cava, ascending aorta, and pulmonary trunk attach to the base. It is directed backwards and to the right, opposite the apex. The base lies opposite the apex and in front of thoracic vertebrae T5–T8 when lying down, descending to T6–T9 when standing. It is separated from the vertebral column by the oblique pericardial sinus, esophagus, and aorta.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with shortness of breath and chest pain. On examination, he has a prominent sternal angle. A CT scan reveals an enlarged mediastinal lymph node at the level of the tracheal bifurcation. Which of the following anatomical structures is most likely to be found at the same level as the bifurcation of the trachea?

options.B: Junction of the azygos vein and superior vena cava
options.D: Superior border of the aortic arch

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Junction of the azygos vein and superior vena cava Explanation: The sternal angle ( angle of Louis) is a palpable, transverse ridge on the sternum located approximately 5 cm below the suprasternal notch. It serves as a critical anatomical landmark for various significant structures and anatomical events. These include: The second costal cartilage articulates with the sternum at this level on both sides, making it a key reference point for counting ribs. It corresponds to the level of the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae . A horizontal plane passing through this level divides the superior mediastinum from the inferior mediastinum . The arch of the aorta both begins and ends at this level. The trachea bifurcates into the right and left principal bronchus at this level. The pulmonary trunk divides into the right and left pulmonary arteries here. The upper border of the heart is located at this level. The azygos vein arches over the root of the right lung and empties into the superior vena cava at this level. (Option B) Left atrium of the heart (Option A) lies posteriorly and is located lower than the sternal angle, around the T6-T7 vertebral level. Origin of the thoracic duct (Option C) : is in the abdomen at the cisterna chyli , at the level of the L1-L2 vertebrae, far below the level of the sternal angle. Superior border of the aortic arch (Option D) : is located slightly above the level of the sternal angle, but its lower border (or the beginning and end of the arch) aligns with the T4-T5 level.

questions.question: All the following are contents of the posterior mediastinum except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pulmonary trunk Explanation: Pulmonary trunk is the content of middle mediastinum. Mediastinum: The mediastinum is an anatomical region between the two lungs in the thoracic cavity. Boundaries: Extends vertically from the thoracic inlet (superior thoracic aperture) to the diaphragm. Anterior - Sternum Posterior - Thoracic vertebral column The posterior boundary of the mediastinum is longer than the anterior because of the oblique alignment of the superior thoracic aperture and the posteroinferior curvature of the diaphragm. Laterally - mediastinal pleura, which are reflections of the parietal pleura. It is divided into superior and inferior mediastinum by the sternal plane which passes horizontally from the manubriosternal joint to T4 to T5 vertebra. Anatomical Divisions: 1. Superior Mediastinum: Located above the sternal angle (manubriosternal joint) Contains critical structures such as: Trachea and initial part of the bronchi Esophagus Great vessels: aortic arch, brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid and subclavian arteries Thymus gland (or its remnants in adults) Various nerves: vagus, phrenic, and cardiac nerves, left RLN Lymph nodes Thoracic duct 2. Inferior Mediastinum: Located below the sternal angle and is further divided into anterior, middle, and posterior mediastinum. Anterior Mediastinum Middle Mediastinum Posterior Mediastinum Lies between the sternum and the pericardium Contains loose connective tissue, lymph nodes, and remnants of the thymus, sterno -pericardial ligaments. Provides surgical access to the heart and great vessels The broadest part of the inferior mediastinum Contains the heart enclosed in the pericardial sac Contains the roots of great vessels: ascending aorta, pulmonary trunk, and pulmonary veins, tracheal bifurcation and bronchi Includes the phrenic nerves and cardiac plexus Extends from the posterior pericardium to the vertebral column Contains important structures such as: (Option A, B, C) Descending thoracic aorta Esophagus Azygos and hemiazygos veins Thoracic duct Sympathetic trunks and splanchnic nerves Lymph nodes

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with exertional chest pain radiating to his left arm. Coronary angiography reveals a significant blockage in the right coronary artery (RCA). Which of the following regions of the heart is most likely at risk of ischemia?

options.A: Anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum
options.B: Lateral wall of the left ventricle
options.C: Posterior one-third of the interventricular septum

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Posterior one-third of the interventricular septum Explanation: The coronary arteries supply blood to specific regions of the heart. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically supplies the right atrium , right ventricle , part of the left ventricle , and the posterior one-third of the interventricular septum in individuals with right-dominant coronary circulation. The posterior descending artery (PDA) branches from the RCA in the right-dominant hearts and supplies the posterior part of the heart. Coronary artery disease is a major cause of death worldwide. It is characterized by a reduced blood flow to the heart muscle (myocardium), depriving it of necessary oxygen. When a major coronary artery is suddenly blocked by an embolus (a plug or clot), the area of the heart muscle that relies on that artery for blood supply becomes ischemic. This lack of blood flow results in the death of the affected myocardial tissue due to necrosis. The 3 most common sites of coronary artery occlusion are: 1. Anterior IV (LAD) branch of the LCA (40–50%). 2. RCA (30–40%). 3. Circumflex branch of the LCA (15–20%). Coronary Artery Lesions Infarct Location Proximal LAD Large anterior wall More Distal LAD LAD (Wraparound) Anteroapical Inferior wall Distal LAD Anteroseptal Early Obtuse, Marginal High lateral wall More Distal Marginal Branch, Circumflex Small lateral wall Circumflex Posterolateral Distal RCA Small inferior wall Proximal RCA Large inferior and posterior wall RCA Right ventricular, usually inferior The anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and the apex of the heart (Options A and D) are supplied by the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, which is a branch of the left coronary artery (LCA). These regions would be affected by a blockage in the LAD, not the RCA. The lateral wall of the left ventricle (Option B) is primarily supplied by the left circumflex (LCX) artery, a branch of the left coronary artery (LCA), and not RCA.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with inferior wall MI. Angiography shows occlusion in the artery supplying the SA node. Which of the following arteries is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Right coronary artery Explanation : The right coronary artery (RCA) supplies the SA node in approximately 60-70% of individuals. Occlusion of the RCA can lead to ischemia in the SA node, resulting in arrhythmias and conduction disturbances. Blood Supply to the Conducting system of the heart: Right Coronary Artery (RCA) supplies SA Node (60%) AV Node (80%) Left Coronary Artery (LCA) supplies SA Node (40%) AV Bundle of His Right bundle and left bundle branches The moderator band was supplied by the interventricular septal branches of the anterior interventricular branch from the left coronary artery. Left coronary artery and Circumflex artery (Options B and C) : In the majority of the population, it is the RCA that supplies the SA node and not the LCA. Posterior interventricular artery (Option D) : Typically supplies the posterior ventricular walls but not the SA node. Reference: Snell’s Clinical Anatomy by Region, 10th Edition, Page 251 pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12819949/

questions.question: A transverse section through the heart at the level of the ventricles reveals several anatomical structures. Which of the following structures is most likely to be observed in this section?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Papillary muscles Explanation: A transverse section at the level of the heart's ventricles cuts through the middle of the ventricles, allowing visualization of internal structures within the ventricles themselves and parts of the surrounding structures. Structures visible in the transverse section of the ventricles of the heart are: Right and Left Ventricles Papillary muscles (Superoposterior, Inferoseptal) Arteries and Veins - Anterior and Posterior Interventricular, Left and Right marginal Sulcus - Anterior and Inferior interventricular Septomarginal trabecula (moderator band) Interventricular septum, muscular part Tricuspid valve, septal leaflet Papillary muscles (Option B) are located within the ventricles and are crucial for the function of the atrioventricular valves. They are clearly visible in a transverse section at the level of the ventricles, as they project into the ventricular chambers and anchor the chordae tendineae. The left atrial appendage (Option A) is located in the left atrium, which is situated above the ventricles. It would not be prominently visible in a transverse section through the ventricles. The aortic arch (Option C) is located above the level of the ventricles and would not be observed in a transverse section through the ventricles. The superior vena cava (Option D) is positioned above the heart and drains into the right atrium.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient is undergoing coronary angiography for chest pain evaluation. The angiogram reveals a dominant left coronary system, with the left coronary artery supplying the majority of the heart's posterior structures. Based on this finding, which of the following statements about cardiac dominance is most accurate? PDA supplies the right atrium. atrium. arises from the left circumflex artery. of the interventricular septum.

options.A: In a left-dominant coronary system, RCA gives off the posterior descending artery (PDA) and the
options.B: In a right-dominant coronary system, the LCA gives off the PDA and the PDA supplies the left
options.C: In a left-dominant coronary system, the PDA is supplied by the left anterior descending artery, which
options.D: In a right-dominant coronary system, the RCA supplies the PDA, which in turn supplies the majority

questions.explanation: supplies the majority of the interventricular septum. Correct Answer: D) In a right-dominant coronary system, the RCA supplies the PDA, which in turn supplies the majority of the interventricular septum. Explanation: Cardiac dominance refers to the variable blood supply pattern to the heart's posterior structures, especially the diaphragmatic surfaces of both ventricles, through the coronary artery that supplies the posterior descending artery (PDA) or posterior interventricular artery. Right Dominance (Option B) Left Dominance (Option A, C) Codominance The posterior interventricular artery (PDA) originates from the right coronary artery (RCA). Occurs in approximately 67% of individuals. The PDA arises from the left circumflex artery (LCX), a branch of the left coronary artery (LCA). Found in about 15% of individuals. Both the RCA and LCX contribute to the formation of the PDA or provide multiple branches serving similar functions. Occurs in approximately 18% of individuals.

questions.question: Match the following coronary arteries with the areas of the heart they predominantly supply: Coronary Arteries Supplied Areas 1) Right conus artery a) Anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum 2) Left anterior descending artery (LAD) b) Infundibulum of right ventricle 3) Left circumflex artery (LCX) c) Posterior interventricular septum 4) Posterior descending artery (PDA) d) Lateral wall of the left ventricle e) Apex of the heart
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1- b, 2- a, 3- d, 4- c Explanation: Artery Supplied Region Right Conus Artery (RCA) Infundibulum of the right ventricle Left Anterior Descending (LAD) Anterior 2/3 of the interventricular septum Left Circumflex Artery (LCX) Lateral wall of the left ventricle Posterior Descending Artery (PDA) Posterior interventricular septum Arterial Supply of the Heart: The arterial supply to the heart is primarily provided by two main coronary arteries: the right coronary artery (RCA) and the left coronary artery (LCA) . These arteries originate from the aortic sinus. Artery Right Coronary Artery (RCA) Left Coronary Artery (LCA) Origin Arises from the right aortic sinus. Arises from the left aortic sinus. Course Moves forward between the pulmonary trunk and right auricle, descending in the right atrioventricular groove. Passes forward between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle, and then splits into two main branches. Branches Right Conus Artery: Supplies the pulmonary conus (infundibulum) and the upper right ventricle. Anterior Ventricular Branches: 2 or 3 in number - supply the anterior surface of the right ventricle. Right Marginal Artery: Largest of anterior ventricular branches - runs along the right margin of the heart towards the apex. Posterior Descending Artery (PDA) or the posterior interventricular artery: Travels in the posterior interventricular groove, supplying the inferior wall of both ventricles and the posterior part of the interventricular septum. This artery often arises from the RCA but can also originate from the LCA in some individuals. Atrial Branches: Supply the right atrium and contribute to the SA node in some individuals. Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD): Travels down the anterior interventricular groove to the heart’s apex. It supplies both ventricles and the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum. Left Circumflex Artery (LCX): Circles around the left margin of the heart in the atrioventricular groove, giving off: Left Marginal Artery: Supplies the left margin of the left ventricle. Anterior and Posterior Ventricular Branches: Supply the left ventricle. Atrial Branches: Supply the left atrium. Lateral or diagonal artery - larger ventricular branch - may arise directly from the trunk of the left coronary artery. A small left conus artery supplies the pulmonary conus.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man is undergoing evaluation for palpitations. ECG reveals a supraventricular tachycardia with HR of 190/min. An echocardiogram reveals hypertrophy of the right ventricle and enlargement of the right ventricular outflow tract. Which structure separates the inflow and outflow tracts in the right ventricle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Supraventricular crest Explanation: The supraventricular crest is located within the right ventricle and separates the inflow tract , which carries blood from the right atrium through the tricuspid valve, from the outflow tract, which directs blood into the pulmonary trunk. It is a thick, muscular “U” shaped structure extending from the interventricular septum to the anterolateral wall of the right ventricle. The crest provides the main attachment for the anterosuperior leaflet of the tricuspid valve. The septal limb of the crest is connected to the septal limbs of the septomarginal trabeculation (moderator band). Crista terminalis (Option A) Located in the right atrium - separates the smooth and rough parts of the atrium, not the right ventricle's inflow and outflow tracts. The moderator band (Option C) facilitates conduction in the right ventricle and contains the right bundle branch (RBB) . Helps prevent overdistension of the right ventricle during systole by acting as a stabilizing structure. It does not separate the inflow and outflow regions. Interventricular septum (Option D) separates the left and right ventricles but does not partition the right ventricle's inflow and outflow tracts.

questions.question: A 36-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness. Her ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia at 170 bpm. Vagal maneuvers temporarily relieve her symptoms. Atrioventricular Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT) is suspected. The reentrant circuit in AVNRT is most likely located in which anatomical region?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Koch’s triangle Explanation: AVNRT is a common type of regular supraventricular tachycardia. It is characterized by a reentrant circuit involving fast and slow pathways, at the level of the AV node. Koch’s triangle is the anatomical region containing the AV node, which is critical in AVNRT. Pathways Involved: Slow pathway: posterior to the AV node. Fast pathway: anterior nodal extension. Anatomical Landmark: Triangle of Koch: Used for catheter ablation (CA), bordered by: Coronary sinus ostium (inferiorly). Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve (anteriorly). Tendon of Todaro (posterosuperiorly). Circuit Involvement: Limited to the AV node and surrounding myocardium. May extend beyond the AV node, including parts of the tricuspid and mitral vestibules. Treatment: Catheter ablation targets the slow (Koch’s Triangle) and fast pathways to interrupt the reentrant circuit. Crista terminalis, His bundle , and Right atrial appendage are not involved in AVNRT. (Options A, B, and D).

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of supraventricular tachycardia. The electrophysiologist plans to perform catheter ablation. Which of the following structures is most likely to be found at the apex of Koch's triangle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Atrioventricular node Explanation : The Triangle of Koch is situated on the right atrial aspect of the interatrial septum. Boundaries: Opening of the coronary sinus The Tendon of Todaro - a collagenous subendocardial band - runs from the central fibrous body to the Eustachian ridge - a part of the fibrous skeleton of the heart. Septal tricuspid leaflet Importance: It helps to localize the AV node - present at the apex of Koch’s triangle . Localising the AV node is important to safely perform radiofrequency catheter ablation within the right atrium in cases of AVNRT. Sinoatrial node (Option A) is located in the upper part of the right atrium, near the opening of the superior vena cava, not in Koch's triangle. While the bundle of His (Option C) is anatomically close to the AV node, it is not typically found at the apex of Koch's triangle. It emerges from the AV node and penetrates the cardiac skeleton. Right bundle branch (Option D) is a continuation of the bundle of His and is found in the interventricular septum, not in Koch's triangle.

questions.question: A 32-year-old man undergoes a coronary angiography after presenting with chest pain. The cardiologist is explaining the venous drainage of the heart as observed in the angiographic images. Which of the following structures is primarily visible on the posterior view of the heart?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Coronary sinus Explanation: Venous drainage of the heart - anterior and posterior view: Anterior View of the Heart Posterior View of the Heart Anterior interventricular sulcus contains LAD and Great cardiac vein Right coronary sulcus contains the right coronary artery and small cardiac vein. Posterior interventricular sulcus contains the posterior descending artery (PDA) and middle cardiac vein. Posterior coronary sulcus contains the coronary sinus. Great cardiac vein , Small cardiac vein - drain into the coronary sinus (Options A and B) Anterior cardiac veins - Directly drain into the right atrium (Option D) Right marginal vein - either joins small cardiac vein or directly drains into the right atrium. Coronary sinus : Main vein of the heart’s drainage system, collecting blood from most of the cardiac veins, and draining into the right atrium. (Option B) Middle cardiac vein -drains into the coronary sinus. Posterior vein of Left ventricle - runs in the diaphragmatic surface of LV and drains into coronary sinus. Oblique vein of the left atrium (Vein of Marshall) : Small vein on the posterior surface of the left atrium, draining into the coronary sinus. Left marginal vein - accompanies marginal branch of LCA and drains into Coronary sinus. Reference: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, Volume 1, 2nd Edition, Pages 276, 277, 278

questions.question: Which of the following veins does not drain into the coronary sinus but rather drains directly into the right atrium?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Anterior Cardiac Veins Explanation: Anterior cardiac veins are small veins that run parallel across the surface of the right ventricle and open directly into the right atrium, not into the coronary sinus. Venous Drainage of the Heart Venous blood from the heart is drained into the right atrium through: Coronary sinus Anterior cardiac veins Venae cordis minimae (Thebesian veins) 1) Coronary Sinus The principal vein of the heart, draining most venous blood into the right atrium. The largest vein of the heart, located in the posterior part of the atrioventricular groove (left posterior coronary sulcus). Develops from the left horn of the sinus venosus and part of the left common cardinal vein. Tributaries of the Coronary Sinus Great Cardiac Vein : Accompanies the anterior interventricular and circumflex arteries, joining the left end of the coronary sinus. (Option A) Middle Cardiac Vein : Accompanies the posterior interventricular artery, joining the coronary sinus near its termination. (Option B) Small Cardiac Vein : Accompanies the right ventricular artery in the right posterior coronary sulcus, draining into the right end of the coronary sinus. (Option D) Posterior Vein of the Left Ventricle Oblique Vein of the Left Atrium (Vein of Marshall) Right Marginal Vein Left Marginal Vein 2) Anterior Cardiac Veins A series of small veins (3 or 4) that run parallel across the surface of the right ventricle, opening into the right atrium. 3) Venae Cordis Minimae (Thebesian Veins) Extremely small veins located in the walls of all four heart chambers, opening directly into their respective chambers. Most numerous in the right atrium.

questions.question: In a chest X-ray given below, the inferior border of the heart is primarily contributed by which structure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Right Ventricle Explanation: The right ventricle forms the majority of the inferior border of the heart in a normal CXR, extending from the inferior vena cava (IVC) to the apex of the heart. Borders of the Heart Right Border : Formed by the right atrium. Extends from the opening of the superior vena cava (SVC) to the inferior vena cava (IVC). Left Border : Formed mainly by the left ventricle. Partly by the left auricle. Extends from the left auricle to the apex of the heart. Inferior Border : Formed by the right ventricle. Partly by the right atrium and left ventricle(near apex). Extends from the opening of the IVC to the apex of the heart. Upper Border : Formed mainly by the left atrium. Partly by the right atrium. Also by the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk.

questions.question: Which sulcus contains major coronary arteries?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Atrioventricular Sulcus Explanation: Atrioventricular (Coronary) Sulcus separates the atria from the ventricles and contains the major coronary arteries. Grooves of the Heart Interatrial Sulcus (of Waterston) : Separates the two atria. (Option A) Atrioventricular (Coronary) Sulcus : Separates the atria from the ventricles. Contains major coronary arteries. Descends obliquely on the anterior surface, separating the right atrium and its auricle from the right ventricle. Curves around the left border and connects with the inferior part. The left anterior part of the AV groove between the left auricle and left ventricle, houses the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery. The posterior part of the AV groove lies between the base and the diaphragmatic surface of the heart, containing the coronary sinus. Anterior Interventricular Sulcus : (Option C) Located near the left border of the heart on the sternocostal surface. Extends from the atrioventricular sulcus to the notch at the cardiac apex. Contains the anterior interventricular artery and the great cardiac vein. Inferior Interventricular Sulcus : (Option D) Closer to the midpoint of the ventricular mass on the diaphragmatic surface. Extends from the atrioventricular sulcus to the notch at the cardiac apex. Contains the posterior interventricular artery and the middle cardiac vein.
